The "Patent and Trademark Office Authorization Act of 1993" authorizes $103,000,000 for salaries and expenses in fiscal year 1994, sourced from the Patent and Trademark Office Fee Surcharge Fund. The "Patent and Trademark Office Authorization Act of 1993" authorizes funds for salaries and expenses in fiscal year 1994, sourced from fees collected under title 35, United States Code, and the Trademark Act of 1946. SEC. 3. Amounts appropriated under this Act may remain available until expended. SEC. 4. Trademark filing fee set at $245, with adjustments not effective before October 1, 1994. SEC. 5. Interim patent extensions authorized. Section 156 of title 35, United States Code is amended to include provisions for extending the regulatory review period for patents under certain circumstances. The owner or its agent may apply for an interim extension of a patent that is the subject of regulatory review, starting 6 months before the patent expiration. The application must include the product under review, the relevant federal statute, and details of the patent and its claims. The applicant must provide information related to the product under regulatory review, including details about the patent, activities undertaken during the review period, and any other information required by the Commissioner for patent extension eligibility. The patent may be eligible for an extension if the product is used commercially. The Commissioner will publish a notice in the Federal Register and issue a certificate of interim extension for up to 1 year. The owner of the patent can apply for up to 4 subsequent interim extensions, except in certain cases where only 1 extension is allowed. The owner of record of the patent, or its agent, may apply for only 1 subsequent interim extension under this paragraph. Each subsequent application must be made 60 days before, and ending 30 days before, the expiration of the preceding interim extension. Each certificate of interim extension shall be recorded in the official file of the patent and considered part of the original patent. Any interim extension granted shall terminate 60 days after the product receives permission for commercial marketing. The patent can be further extended for up to 5 years from the original expiration date if the applicant notifies the Commissioner within 60 days of receiving permission for commercial marketing. If the patent is subject to specific conditions, the extension can be from the date of approval for commercial marketing. The patent can be extended for up to 5 years from the original expiration date if the applicant notifies the Commissioner within 60 days of receiving permission for commercial marketing. Rights derived from any extended patent are limited to uses or methods under regulatory review during the extension period. SEC. 6. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, is amended to clarify and update various subsections regarding rights and provisions. SEC. 7. PATENT TERM EXTENSIONS FOR AMERICAN LEGION. The design patents for the badges of the American Legion, American Legion Women's Auxiliary, and Sons of the American Legion are renewed and extended for 14 years from the date of enactment of the Act, with all associated rights and privileges. The design patent for the badge of the Sons of the American Legion, numbered 92,187, is renewed and extended for 14 years from the date of enactment of the Act, with all rights and privileges. SEC. 8. INTERVENING RIGHTS. The renewals and extensions of patents under section 6 will not result in infringement for any use of the patent's subject matter that began after the patent expired but before the enactment of this Act.
